body: One other thing -- if we did this, I don't think we'd have to do anything to address #1762 as this would take care of that issue as well.  `config.include_context "shared group name"` would obviously validate that `"shared group name"` is a top-level shared example group that can be included anywhere.

> - Add a new config.include_context API that is similar to config.include but is for shared contexts. This would solve the "no obvious way to auto-include a shared group everywhere" issue mentioned above and provide a sister API to config.include for consistency.

I like this idea, I use `config.include` stuff a lot and this would just be one more nicety in defining it.

> - Stop using the metadata passed to shared_context as a means to determine which example groups should have the context auto-included, instead allowing it the metadata to get applied to including example groups.
> 
> This is a breaking change and either has to wait until RSpec 4 or we have to add a config option. I lean towards the latter -- something like `config.use_shared_example_group_metadata_for_auto_inclusion = true` (although that is a bit ambiguous -- the `config.include_context` API would still use it for auto-inclusion -- maybe someone has a better idea?)

I'm fine with this, it's similar to how we changed the metadata symbol means true stuff in RSpec 2 -> 3. How about make the config option a "behaviour" rather than a on / off flag? `config.shared_context_metadata_behaviour = :included_in_examples` or `config.shared_context_metadata_behaviour = :apply_to_examples`

issue.title: If shared_examples block has example metadata they are running in other specs
issue.body:
This problem only occurs when running the full set of specs on the rails project. When a shared_examples block has identical example metadata as the top-level describe block in another spec, those examples are automatically included in that spec as well. 

Work Around: Move the example metadata inside the shared_example, either directly on the tests or in a describe block.

Using rspec-rails 3.1.0

Code example:

```
describe FooController, example_field: 'Foobar' do
   it 'will run this test' do
   ....
   end
end

describe Bar do
   shared_examples 'some shared example, example_field: 'Foobar' do
        it 'will also run this test' do
         ....
       end 
   end
end
```

issue.title: New definition of shared_context doesn't actually overwrite the previous one
issue.body:
``` ruby
RSpec.shared_context 'clear state', :reset_after do
  before(:context) { puts 'before :reset_after context'}
  after(:context) { puts 'after :reset_after context' }
end

RSpec.shared_context 'clear state', :reset_after do
  before(:context) { puts 'before :reset_after context 2' }
  after(:context) { puts 'after :reset_after context 2' }
end

RSpec.describe do
  context 'some', :reset_after do
    it('some') {}
  end
end
```

After invoking this sample code `The new definition will overwrite the original one.` warning is printed. However, hooks from both "old" and "new" definitions of shared_context are printed.

So it looks like the "new" definition didn't actually overwrite the old one.

issue.title: Checking in after hook that shared_context has been included
issue.body:
I have the following use case:

Cookies are generally cleared after each example in integration tests that use browser. It's done to prevent state leakage between tests.

But I think it would be good to give possibility to not clear state between scenarios inside some context and clear state only after context. Small illustration:

``` ruby
feature 'some feature' do
  before(:all) do
    create_user
    create_some_data_for_user
  end

  before(:each) do
    login
    load_page_with_that_data
  end

  scenario '1' { do_action_1_with_that_data_without_changing_it }
  scenario '2' { do_action_2_with_that_data_without_changing_it }
end
```

Here `login` call inside before(:each) hook is needed just because cookies are cleared. But state is already shared using `before(:all)` so it's pretty pointless to clear cookies between examples of that context.

Therefore I would like to write the following:

``` ruby
feature 'some feature' do
  include_context 'reset after'

  before(:all) do
    create_user
    create_some_data_for_user
  end

  def before(:each) do
    load_page_with_that_data
  end

  scenario '1' { do_action_1_with_that_data_without_changing_it }
  scenario '2' { do_action_2_with_that_data_without_changing_it }
end
```

By including that context I would like to tell that cookies should be cleared only after the context, not after each example.

But I haven't found a way to check inside `config.after` hook whether a particular shared_context has been included into one of parent example groups. I think it could be done in RSpec e.g. by setting some flag (e.g. metadata) inside `find_and_eval_shared` method. User of RSpec would be able to use that flag inside `config.after { |example| ... }` to check if a context was included or not.

issue.title: Auto-included shared contexts are not subject to the same scoping rules that manually included ones are
issue.body:
Currently, when you define a shared example group with metadata, the implementation does this:

``` ruby
mod = Module.new
(class << mod; self; end).__send__(:define_method, :included) do |host|
  host.class_exec(&block)
end
RSpec.configuration.include mod, *metadata_args
```

It delegates to `configuration.include` in order to make the shared group auto-included in example groups that have matching metadata.

There's a discrepancy with the scoping rules of shared example groups, though: if the shared group is defined within a nested group it is only available for manual inclusion (using `include_context` or similar) within that group or a nested group.  With the metadata auto-inclusion, the shared group would still be included in any matching example group, even if it's "out of scope" according to our manual inclusion scoping rules.

We should probably address this but maybe in the 4.0 timeframe?

/cc @JonRowe

issue.title: Feature: Sanctioned Support Helper Inclusion
issue.body:
I got this brilliant error message today:

```
`method_missing': `whatever` is not available on an example group (e.g. a `describe` or `context` block). It is only available from within individual examples (e.g. `it` blocks) or from constructs that run in the scope of an example (e.g. `before`, `let`, etc). (RSpec::Core::ExampleGroup::WrongScopeError)
```

Then I began to wonder why there's no built in way to include support helpers easily. Here's a rough sketch of what I'm thinking would be incredibly useful:

``` ruby
RSpec.support(:controller_support, type: :controller) do
  group_helpers do
    def helper_for_a_describe_block
    end
  end
  example_helpers do
    def helper_for_a_let_block
    end
    def helper_for_an_it_block
    end
  end
end
```

I was earlier repeating this pattern all over the place:

``` ruby
module ControllerSupport
  # Methods to add to both example groups and examples
  module Global
  end

  # Methods to add to example groups (i.e. `describe` or `context` blocks)
  module GroupHelpers
  end

  # Add methods to add to examples (i.e. `it` blocks) or constructs that run in
  # the scope of an example (e.g. `before`, `let`, etc)
  module ExampleHelpers; end
end

RSpec.configure do |config|
  config.extend ControllerSupport::Global, type: :controller
  config.extend ControllerSupport::GroupHelpers, type: :controller
  config.include ControllerSupport::Global, type: :controller
  config.include ControllerSupport::ExampleHelpers, type: :controller
end
```

Right now, I use this hackiness to do the dirty work, and it's been a pleasure so far:

``` ruby
def RSpec.support(module_name, options = {})
  RSpec.configure do |config|
    if defined?(module_name::Global)
      config.extend module_name::Global, options
      config.include module_name::Global, options
    end
    if defined?(module_name::GroupHelpers)
      config.extend module_name::GroupHelpers, options
    end
    if defined?(module_name::ExampleHelpers)
      config.include module_name::ExampleHelpers, options
    end
  end
end

# Now I can do this!
module ModelSupport; end
RSpec.support(ModelSupport, type: :model)
```

I'd love to implement this myself with some guidance if you all are interested.

Cheers! :beers:

body: One update to this idea: we could consider making `config.include` support shared group names in addition to module references, rather than introducing a new `config.include_context` API.

issue.title: Misleading warning for `shared_context`s with meta attributes
issue.body:
Greetings, gentlemen.

So I wanted to be a smartass and keep the same name for the different spec types:

``` ruby
# This shared context is available for both `:feature` and
# `:controller` specs, utilizing `Warden` and `Devise` helpers
# correspondingly. No need to specify `type` in `:controller` specs.
shared_context :current_user, type: :feature do
  let(:user) { create :user }

  before do
    login_as user, scope: :user
  end
end

shared_context :current_user do
  let(:user) { create :user }

  before do
    sign_in user
  end
end
```

And it works great, but know I'm getting this warning:

```
WARNING: Shared example group 'current_user' has been previously defined at:
  ~/dev/ruby/apps/{...}/spec/support/shared_contexts/current_user.rb:4
...and you are now defining it at:
  ~/dev/ruby/apps/{...}/spec/support/shared_contexts/current_user.rb:12
The new definition will overwrite the original one.
```

The thing is that the new definition **isn't overwriting the original one**. They behave as expected in the `:feature` and `:controller` specs correspondingly.

Apologies for my ignorance, I don't know if those attributes supported or how the `shared_context` method implemented, but those `context`s are definitely treated as different ones and the warning logic should probably be updated.

body:
> One update to this idea: we could consider making config.include support shared group names in addition to module references, rather than introducing a new config.include_context API.

Then it's switching behaviour based on type of the argument? I'm slightly negative on that.

> This is a breaking change and either has to wait until RSpec 4 or we have to add a config option.

I lean towards the former. This doesn't seem important enough to justify introducing more config, RSpec 4 is in theory not that far away (... any reason we shouldn't just call master 4 and start working on it?), and there would be a way to transition to the new behaviour with `include_context`.

> Then it's switching behaviour based on type of the argument? I'm slightly negative on that.

I wouldn't consider it switching behavior. Ultimately it's including a module -- either a manually defined and referenced one from the user, or a `RSpec::Core::SharedExampleGroupModule` created for the user when they defined the shared example group and referenced via the group name.

issue.title: shared_examples with `js: true` are wrongfully included in `js: true` contexts
issue.body:
In this test:

``` ruby
RSpec.shared_examples :shared_test, js: true do
  it { expect(true).to eq(false) }
end

RSpec.feature 'Test feature' do
  context 'Test context', js: true do
    it { expect(true).to eq(true) }
  end
end
```

:shared_test examples are executed in `Test context`, although we're not including it.
